comments.author: sh m

comments.text:
+sh m Having read the Book of Mormon several times cover to cover and 
having once been an active fully practicing Mormon, the discrepancies I 
discovered between the Book of Mormon account and actual archeological 
findings always bothered me deeply.
Nephi and his people came from a culture that understood and utilized 
advanced metallurgy.
Labans steel sword and body armor, Nephis steel bow and tools he molted and 
crafted himself to build a ship. 1 Nephi 4:9, 1 Nephi 16:18, 1 Nephi 
17:9,10, 11 and 16, 2 Nephi 5:14, 2 Nephi 5:15.
No such metallurgy existed in the new world until the Europeans.
The Native Americans used copper, bronze, silver and gold, all natural 
elements,  to craft decorative and ceremonial jewelry and items but made no 
attempt at creating steel or molting iron. Archeologists have never 
discovered any iron or steel tools, weapons or implements in the Americas 
before the Europeans.
How is it that the supposed descendants of a people with this technological 
knowledge and ability would lose this knowledge? How is it that no iron or 
steel weapons, tools or implements have ever been discovered in a land that 
was supposedly covered with these descendants? Has this ever happened 
before any place else on earth?
The Book of Mormon states that Nephi and his family traveled South to the 
Red Sea and continued down the Arabian Peninsula for the space of eight 
years to present day Yemen. They are then commanded to build a timber 
construction ship. 1 Nephi 17:1, 1 Nephi 17:8.
To my knowledge there has never been timber to build a ship growing in the 
region. Perhaps someone would research this.
Lehi, Nephi and their people sailed across the Indian and Pacific oceans, 
around the world, without making landfall to Central America. Really?
That would be tough to do with a modern sailing vessel.
They loaded all manner of seeds and fruits from the area to take with them. 
1 Nephi 17:6. And they began to till the earth and plant the seeds they had 
brought which produced crops in abundance. 1 Nephi 18:24, 2 Nephi 5:11
No evidence of any grain, fruit or vegetable from the middle east has ever 
been found growing in America or preserved in any tomb or temple.
According to The Book of Mormon the Americas were set apart for a land for 
Lehi's descendants. Throughout the Book of Mormon no contact with any 
people living in America previous to Lehi's people are recorded. 2 Nephi 
1:5 thru 9, Alma 63:, Mosiah 8:.  
There are numerous references in the Book of Mormon to horses and chariots 
being used in the Americas. 1 Nephi 18:25, 2 Nephi 12:7 and many more.
There were no horses in the Americas before the Europeans (Spanish) 
introduced them.
There has never been a wheel or any wheeled conveyance found in the 
Americas before the Europeans. Such technology would not have been 
abandoned or forgotten by the natives. There has never been a road found in 
the Americas built for a wheeled conveyance by the natives.
Joseph Smith's account states that the four sets of plates, three gold and 
one brass, that he translated the Book of Mormon from was written in Hebrew 
and Egyptian.
No such written or spoken language or any remnant there of has ever been 
found in America. The Mayan hieroglyphs of Central America are unique and 
bear no resemblance to any middle eastern language or hieroglyph. They date 
from 200AD to 600AD. The peak of their civilization. 35,000 or so are in 
known existence and have been decoded and can now be read. The written 
language is now being taught to Guatemalans of Mayan decent.
There is no mention of anything contained in the Book of Mormon. Bear in 
mind Mormon hides the plates in the hill Cumorah between 400 and 421 AD. 
You would think something as big as the coming of Christ to America,  civil 
and social rivalries, enormous wars and mass battles would have made the 
news! 1 Nephi 19:4
Then there is the incontrovertable DNA research, findings and science 
publications on the anthropology of the Americas.
My eyes were opened in 2007. I have no axe to grind or vendetta against the 
Mormon Church. I have many friends and family that are active Mormons.
I have a strong unwavering personal relationship with God and Jesus Christ.
Truth is Truth. I ask only that you do your own study and research and draw 
your own conclusions.

comments.text:
Mormonism is a young religion, and is fundamentalist.   There is no formal 
way to be a secular mormon.   People who become secular are considered 
"inactive" in the church and are not given access to Mormon temples.

There are many secular Christians.  One can see the problems in the news 
concerning actions by the large percentage of Christian Fundamentalists. 

Most Mormons know the basics of their religion, and do not do any intense 
study of Mormon scripture nor history.   With the Internet, these things 
are searchable, and non-Mormons create web content that highlight conflicts 
between current Mormon status quo and past teachings/history.  People will 
stumble onto these things in their search results.  Future Web tools will 
provide an even more cohesive search result, which will make these things 
even more visible.

This will undoubtedly affect the Church.   Church growth has remained at 
the same levels for a decade, and the Church has been self-searching the 
cause.   I think it has only been recently that the Church has realized 
that the stagnant growth, even when the number of missionaries has been 
greatly increased, is due to people having been informed about imbalances 
in Mormon teachings, history and policy before the missionaries knock on 
their door.

These imbalances have not been formally addressed by the Church.  The 
default policy has been to let these things fade away by not repeating 
them.  The Church may need to be more overt in their response to these 
issues.   What makes this difficult is that the Church needs to present 
their current status in such a way that it does not make previous Church 
Leaders look bad.   It is a serious offense in  the Mormon church to 
criticise Church leaders, especially in a public forum.

For example, the implementation of Joseph Smith's polygamy is very 
troublesome.  The only way to approach it sanely is secularly, to state 
what the records show and be honest about the embarrassing parts.   
Polygamy in and of itself is concerning.  The records show that Joseph 
Smith was practicing polygamy while publically denying it, which is even 
worse.   When the newspaper called "The Nauvoo Expositor", funded and owned 
by disenfranchised mormons, printed it's first issue, which was about 
Joseph's Polygamy, Joseph Smith, as the commander of the Nauvoo Legion, the 
city's local militia, told them to destroy the printing press.   This was 
the reason Joseph Smith was detained in Carthage Jail, where he was then 
assassinated.   He denied people their first amendment rights.   Explaining 
this away is very difficult.  Some members at this time considered Joseph 
to be a "fallen prophet".

Currently, when missionaries are asked about polygamy, they respond that 
this is about another Church (implying the Fundamentalist LDS Church whom 
still practice polygamy).  IN a sense, that statement is correct.   The 
current LDS Church bares little resemblance to the Church in Joseph's day. 
  Reconciling this is difficult.﻿

comments.text:
+SATAN IS THE WORD! ...And there it is! The famous red herring fallacy poor 
debaters fall trap to when trapped into a corner. I really wanted you to 
spare yourself some dignity and man up to your mistake, but instead you 
pull this crap argument out in an attempt to shift the gaze away from your 
blatant mistake.

I probably shouldn't encourage this type of red herring by answering your 
poorly constructed argument, but just because it's too easy to knock over 
that straw house, I'll give you your retort: "why you waste your time 
fighting something that you don't believe in"
I'm not.
I'm arguing against people who believe in any gods, that is not at all the 
same thing as arguing with, or against a god, and the fact that you can so 
easily switch the two around (Me arguing against you/ Me arguing against 
your god) might have something to do with the fact that psychologically 
speaking, your god, or at least the part of your mind you consult with when 
trying to determine god's will, is the same part of your mind you use to 
consult yourself in a decision making process.
More specifically, I'm arguing against the idea of believing in claims 
before there is sufficient evidence to believe them or before they're 
proven and meet their burden of proof. Whatever scale of evidence the 
majority of the world's population is using for determining truth in 
regards to religion, clearly isn't working since everybody believes in 
different religions, and the particular religion an individual subscribes 
to has to do largely with their geographical location.
I am arguing against the idea of faith. It could even be said that I'm 
arguing against the idea of a god (although that's not entirely true, as I 
will gladly accept the hypothesis if there is ever what a scientist would 
consider sufficient evidence for it). But arguing against the idea of a 
god, and arguing with a god are not at all the same thing, and it's 
ridiculous that you mix up those two things and present it as some sort of 
argument.
Ask yourself this, if the majority of the world thought the Easter Bunny 
was real, and spent a large portion of their lives worshiping it, would you 
not have a say in the matter? Would you just say to yourself "Well, I can't 
tell them they're wrong, because if I were to voice my opinion, I'd be 
admitting to myself that there IS an Easter bunny, just by arguing with the 
idea." Of course you wouldn't! That is the most ridiculous logic ever!

downright hilarious! What I find even more humorous than your 
interpretation of these articles is the fact that I gave you three 
opportunities to google search it, none of which you took advantage of.

The Big Bang Theory has not been disproved. There ARE some scientists that 
have made hypothesizes that there was no big bang. Scientists are suppose 
to do this. They question everything, even the big theories. The fact that 
there's a hypothesis out there does not mean the hypothesis is true until 
it is demonstrated to be so, and as of now, the amount of evidence in favor 
of a big bang widely outweighs the evidence against it. The fact that 
there's an article on the web that sells this story for more than it really 
is, just a proposition, and that you've taken that click hungry article's 
word on this (and technically speaking, you took it one step further by 
calling this "Disproving the Big Bang Theory" when the article clearly 
states "MAY be completely wrong") is very laughable. I don't know how you 
read this and though two scientists forming a hypothesis about the universe 
that didn't include the big bang theory equated to the big bang theory 
being disproved, and honestly I'm thinking your kind of a dumb-ass at this 
point if you don't know the difference.

It may be the case that the big bang theory will be disproved, as could be 
the case with anything scientific. The fact that anything and everything 
can be disproved is one of the strong points of science. Every theory must 
be disprovable, every idea capable of being questioned.

Unless you actually intend to admit your fault here, I don't have any 
interest in allowing you to comment further on this thread. I don't have 
much interest in arguing with someone who's thick headed enough to deny a 
fault even when they were specifically called out on it.

+Richard Holmes I've run into two or three anti-Mormon Christians, and I've 
got to say, they are pretty annoying, and I think I know what you're 
referring too. There is quite a bit of misinformation on Mormons in general 
(like the people who think they worship Joseph smith), and I'd guess a lot 
of it comes from ex-Mormon Christians trying to impress their Christian 
friends with storytelling.
Concerning the evidence you provided:
I don't have any way to verify that your "certain feeling" was in fact not 
a human emotion, or natural chemical reaction in the brain, and I don't 
think you do either. Since you believe there to be supernatural forces, it 
seems highly likely that you could easily mislabel a human feeling as 
divine.
Everything picking back up where you left it doesn't seem like that big of 
a miracle (unless time literally rewinded XD, but I don't think that's what 
you're talking about). The event also doesn't seem to be related or infer 
LDS doctrine. There's nothing about it that specifically says or hints that 
it was a god's doing. If any human perceived coincidence qualifies under 
good evidence, then that's a lot of opportunities for good evidence of a 
variety of superstitions.
"Just this one example of what I'm talking about proves that that 
experience back in 97 was of the divine!" I don't see what quality about 
this event proves that it's divine in origin. Many people of different 
faiths have similar, and more impressive stories about their religion, so 
if you're experience qualifies for proof of your religion, why doesn't 
theirs?

Let's go back to an earlier reply you gave me. My question was:"What 
reasons do you have to believe that your religion is correct as opposed to 
the many others out there who believe theirs is correct" Your reply was 
this: "As I said earlier!  It's not that there are not truths in other 
churches!..it's that the Mormons do have the fullness!"
You did not answer the question here, you either purposefully, or 
accidentally dodged the question by saying something almost every religious 
person would agree on. Other religious people would gladly agree that other 
churches are correct to some degree. The question I asked was what reasons 
you have to believe that this particular Christian denomination is correct 
as opposed to the thousands of others you haven't even had a chance to be 
exposed to?
Just statistically speaking, the odds seem incredibly low that you would be 
born into/Happened upon (Don't know if you're a convert or not) the correct 
church. It also seems very premature to assume that you've found the one 
full truth, when we know that billions of people claim the exact same, or 
similar thing and that a person's religious affiliation is mostly dependent 
on their geographical location. E.g. If you were born into a Muslim family 
in a Muslim majority country, It'd be extremely likely that you'd be a 
Muslim right now claiming the same thing about full truth you are right now.
To believe a claim as large as that, knowing that billions of people are 
claiming a similar stance on several different premises, with their own

comments.text:
+Richard Holmes First, starting a discussion with, "Pull your head out of 
your ass!" is not exactly something President Monson would condone, nor is 
it an effective way to "sell" the information you're about to convey.

Second, you actually nailed one of my points.  NOBODY else was WRITING 
scripture in the 19th century.  The reason 17th Century English was the 
scriptural vernacular is because the Bible was TRANSLATED in the 17th 
Century.  Now, why would somebody living in the 19th Century "translate" 
his book into vernacular that nobody had actively spoken in several 
generations?  The answer is MARKETING.  People are more likely to "buy" 
scriptural claims if they stylistically match already existing 
scripture...which is itself devoid of empirical support, by the way.

As for Native Americans' being, "born of Egyptian gentile (woman)," I'll 
grant that the Human Genome Project and others like it have concluded that 
ALL modern humans are descended and evolved from Central/North African 
ancestors.  However, unless you can provide evidence, such as links to 
peer-reviewed Historical and/or Scientific research, then your claim of 
Egyptian gentile ancestry is false, as are your claims of Jewish DNA among 
Native American populations...and for the same reason.

In any discussion or debate, the one who claims, "This IS," or, "This 
exists," is the one who carries the burden of proof.  You want me to 
believe?  Fine.  Furnish evidence that corroborates the Book of Mormon OR 
the Bible.  The only condition is that, as the rules of logic dictate, 
scripture cannot be self-affirming.  Corroboration must come from 
NON-scriptural sources.  I'll be genuinely happy to check out any relevant 
links you'd care to post.

As for the alleged Book of Abraham, when countless people who have 
dedicated their lives to the study of a particular subject say the 
conclusions of somebody with NO formal study of the subject matter are 
utterly erroneous, I'm inclined to believe the experts.  Either 
those experts are all wrong, OR Joseph Smith was a gifted fantasy author.  
I believe option #2, and if we were talking about anybody BUT Joseph Smith 
YOU would, too.  However, as discussed above, if you'd care to present 
evidence...other than that which Agrippa The Mighty has already 
rebutted...then I'd love to be as educated as possible about the subject.

Just remember that the rules of logic prohibit acceptance of, "The book is 
true because it says so in the book."

comments.text:
Due to pressure from outsiders, the Mormon Church put out an official memo 
about Joseph Smith's 34 wives.   I did not hear about this memo from the 
Church.   I did see a blurb about it on a news channel.  So I checked it 
out and went to the URL that was provided.  I was taken to lds.org, the 
official website of the Mormon Church, to a document that one can only find 
using an alphabetic index, meaning you have to know the name of the 
document in order to find it.

In that memo, it listed all of Joseph Smith's wives.   I already knew that 
Joseph Smith had multiple wives, but that is all I knew.  The section of 
the Doctrine and Covenants, the core scripture which contains modern day 
revelation, is 132.  I knew that this section was written in 1842.  What I 
saw in this memo was that Joseph's first plural wife was in 1831, 11 years 
BEFORE section 132 was made part of the D&C.

I had to go outside the Church memo to learn more.  Joseph's first plural 
wife was Fanny Alger.   She was just 16 years old.   She had lived in the 
Smith household for 2 years.   There is a statement in the header of 
section 132 in the D&C that says that Joseph Smith knew about the 
revelation allowing plural marriage in 1831.   I could find no other 
information about when Joseph received this revelation nor when it had been 
first written down.   There is nothing written about who was first told 
about this revelation.   The only thing written down is that Joseph Smith 
had an emissary go to the Alger household and tell Fanny's Father that 
Joseph Smith loved his daughter and desired to marry her.  The father said 
yes, so the emissary asked the mother.   The mother said yes, so the 
Emissary asked Fanny.   Fanny said yes.   Joseph and Fanny were married 
that day.   It is not known if Emma Smith, Joseph's first wife, knew that 
this had taken place.  What we do know is that a short time later, Fanny 
left LDS society and married a non-member by surname Custer and spent the 
rest of her life with him.  Fanny's brother asked Fanny about her 
relationship with Joseph Smith shortly before her death, and she told him 
it was between her and God.

Although it was common for young girls to marry men in their late 20s in 
the early 1800s, I just didn't feel right about this.  I did not like it 
that Fanny had lived in the Smith household for 2 years prior to this 
marriage.  I guess what bothered me the most was that the record is not 
clear on what Emma Smith knew and how she felt about it.  The Church memo 
about Joseph's multiple marriages did state that Emma and Joseph had a lot 
of conflict over this, and I assume that this was the reason that Emma 
Smith did not go to Utah with Brigham Young and the Saints.

Oliver Cowdery, a witness to the Book of Mormon (who claimed to have seen 
the Angel Moroni) was very upset about this first plural marriage.   He 
called it a dirty, filty, nasty little affair.   Oliver was eventually 
excommunicated from the Mormon Church because of this and other things.   I 
tried to give Joseph Smith the benefit of the doubt and not assume that 
Joseph had sex with Fanny before marriage.   What bother's me is that 
Joseph did not try hard enough to avoid the appearance of Evil.   If Fanny 
was to live with the Smiths, he should have had a strict policy of hands 
off, like she had been one of his own children.   I was disillusioned by 
Joseph's behavior, which motivated me to look closer.

I also didn't like how Joseph Smith married women who were already married. 
 Joseph's marriage to them was for Eternity-Only, meaning that the marriage 
didn't take effect until both of them were dead.  What I didn't like about 
this is that it took away a man's wife forever.  When her current husband 
died, he'd never see her again.  Worse, since he would be alone in the next 
life, he would never make it to the highest level of the Celestial Kingdom, 
damning the level of his eternal progress.  He would be a servant forever 
(unless he decided to have a plural marriage).

So I continued looking into other things.  The next big thing I found was 
about how the translation of the Book of Mormon actually happened.  I won't 
go into the details, but it really broke my heart.   And when I had learned 
about all the changes that had been made to the Book of Mormon after it was 
first published, I was mad.   The Church continues to make changes to the 
Book of Mormon as needs occur.   One of the later changes to the Book of 
Mormon was to change the phrase "White and Delightsome People" to "Pure and 
delightsome people".   This is a big difference.  IMHO, it was done to 
cover up verses in the Book of Mormon which sound racist.

So I did an intense study for a week.   I skipped meals, I skipped sleep.   
I found so much that I was overwhelmed by sorrow.   I was the Mormon who 
always helped people move, who cared about other people's kids, and tried 
to teach the members how to be a good human being.  I feel betrayed by the 
Church leadership over that last 2 centuries.   How could they do this?  

 I have not yet asked to have my name removed from the records of the 
Church, but I will eventually, when my children and extended family are 
ready for the shock.  I'll probably wait until my parents are dead.  In the 
meantime, I have to figure out what I believe in now.﻿

comments.text:
Fading influence of the Christian world view

The weakening allegiance to a Christian world view is evident in many ways.
As we have already shown, many bodies of organized Christianity have 
repudiated orthodox theology.
Some statistics suggest that popular religious opinions are still fairly 
orthodox. But these statistics belie the truth.
Although 90-95% of Americans say they believe in God, most of them have a 
faith that can only be described as extremely shallow.
After World War II, 87% of those questioned said that they were absolutely 
certain of God's existence (15). By 1964, the portion with no doubts had 
fallen to 77% of the population, and by 1981, to 62% (16).
In 1990, six out of seven said that it is okay not to believe in God (17).
The consensus that Jesus is God is also misleading. Many fewer now believe 
that it is necessary to accept Jesus in order to be saved. In 1964, a bare 
majority, 51%, still believed that Jesus is the only way. But the same 
measure slumped to 38% by 1981 (18). Since then, the measure must have 
slumped further.
Twenty years ago, 70% identified the Bible as the word of God, but about 
three sevenths of these also said that it contains mistakes (19).
Belief in an afterlife remains prevalent. In 1990, 82% agreed that there is 
an afterlife including heaven and hell (20). But only 4% expected to go to 
hell, and 45% also believed in ghosts (21).
Almost a fourth of the populace accepts the occult to some degree. A full 
31% believe that some people have magical powers, 28% believe in 
witchcraft, 24% in black magic, 20% in voodoo (22).
A survey in 1990 looked at opinions on leading public issues. On no issue 
did a majority feel that they needed religious guidance to the right 
answer. On almost all issues, a majority did not even know what position 
their religion took (23).
Perhaps the most dramatic proof that America is forsaking its Christian 
heritage emerges from the history of how the law views Christianity. In 
1892, the Supreme Court ruled that "our civilization and our institutions 
are emphatically Christian" (24). Today, the Supreme Court has gone so far 
in enforcing separation of church and state that, in the opinion of former 
Chief Justice Rehnquist, it has become antireligious. In a dissenting 
opinion, he said that "the tone of the Court's opinion . . . bristles with 
hostility to all things religious in public life" (25).
comments.author: BobMcDanielRobertson

comments.text:
Apostasy in the Church
Fading influence of the church

Despite the rosy statistic cited earlier—that half of the Americans 
interviewed in 1991 reported that they had gone to a religious service in 
the last week—a full picture of the evidence shows that church attendance 
is falling catastrophically.
Researchers have determined that about half of those who say they went to a 
service are lying (9). Actual church attendance is about half the figure 
gleaned by telephone surveys.
By 1996, the same kind of telephone survey found that only 37% of adults 
reported going to a service in the last week (10).
With few exceptions, almost all denominations are losing members. 
Practically the only religious assemblies registering growth in recent 
years have been megachurches (11).
In confidential interviews, 27% say that they go to church regularly, but 
58% say that they went regularly as a child (12). The drop is greatest 
among Jews (12% and 31%) and virtually the same for Catholics (41% and 78%) 
and Protestants (34% and 67%) (13).
The proportion of the population saying that religion is important in their 
lives declined from 75% in 1952 to 70% in 1965 and then even more to 53% in 
1978 (14). No doubt the percentage has fallen further in the last thirty 
years.
comments.author: BobMcDanielRobertson

comments.text:
Apostasy in the Church

Secularization of Society

A superficial look at statistics would lead to the conclusion that the 
church in America is thriving. As recently as 1991, almost half of the 
adults reached by telephone reported that they had attended a religious 
service within the last week (2). In surveys done between the late 1970s 
and the early 1990s, about 95% of adult Americans stated that they believe 
in God, about 90% claimed that they pray, about 80% agreed that Jesus was 
God or the Son of God, and about 70% accepted the Bible as the word of God 
(3). It would appear that Christianity still has a strong hold on American 
society. But the appearance is misleading. A deeper look at statistics 
reveals that the influence of Christianity is rapidly declining and in 
danger of disappearing altogether.

Fading influence of the Bible

Although Americans retain a token respect for the Bible, a diminishing 
minority regard it as a guidebook for life.
The finding in the late 70s that about 70% endorsed the Bible as the word 
of God may seem like a sign of healthy fundamentalism. But the comparable 
measure after World War II was 86% (4).
In 1963, an amazing 65% still believed that the Bible is literally true. 
Ten years later, the same measure had dropped to less than 40%, and has 
remained low ever since (5).
In 1990, less than 40% defined sin as "going against God's will," going 
against the Bible," or "violating the Ten Commandments" (6).
In the same survey, only 13% stated that they believe in all Ten 
Commandments. (The unpopularity of the Sabbath law is the main reason for 
the surprisingly low figure.) Only 40% stated that they believe in at least 
five (7).
The many reasons for the Bible slipping to the margins of American 
consciousness include these:
Bible ownership has drastically declined.
The language is changing, making the traditional versions inaccessible to 
today's reader.
Literacy is declining, with the result that people read less and what they 
read is less challenging. For many, the Bible has become hard reading.
The Bible has been banished from public schools, and is ignored or mocked 
in the mass media. Even to post the Ten Commandments in a public place has 
been forbidden.
The Bible receives little attention in the home. As long ago as the late 
70s, only 17% of American parents stated that they had read the Bible with 
their children during the last week (8). If false affirmatives could have 
been sifted out, the true percentage would have been much lower. The 
percentage today would be lower still.
comments.author: BobMcDanielRobertson

comments.text:
Conclusion

Each wind of apostasy that has swept across Christendom has blown people 
away from moorings in sound faith and practice. Few churches remain that 
approximate what they should be, according to God's design laid out in the 
New Testament. Those that still hold fast to their fundamentalist heritage 
find themselves under tremendous pressure to move either toward evangelical 
compromise or cultic authoritarianism, rigidity, and superstition. Will any 
survive as living churches? God is testing His people, to see whether any 
will love Him rather than the world, though it offers them an easy 
religion, without sacrifice or self-denial.

comments.text:
Neofundamentalism and cultic fundamentalism

The segment of the church left behind as evangelicals drifted toward more 
liberal positions kept the name "fundamentalist." But purity and unity 
within fundamentalism did not long survive all the divisive currents in the 
modern church. As late as the 1960s, all fundamentalists could still 
assemble and feel that they shared a common identity. But then the 
fracturing process began. By the 1980s, two new movements had appeared, 
both weighed down by apostate tendencies. One of these has been called 
neofundamentalism. The other I will call cultic fundamentalism.
"Neofundamentalism" was originally a label that fundamentalist opponents of 
Jerry Falwell pinned on his political action movement, known as the Moral 
Majority. The label is useful to signify churches and groups that have 
emerged from fundamentalism and acquired the following characteristics, now 
evident in many with no connection to Jerry Falwell:
They prefer modern translations of the Bible.
In 1950, Time Magazine, reporting on the revival at Wheaton College, spoke 
of it as bearing "the stamp of its strict fundamentalist heritage: no 
movies, smoking, card-playing, dancing or drinking," and it said derisively 
of the readers of Christian Life, a popular Christian magazine in those 
days, "Drinking, smoking, dancing, card-playing and movies they consider 
the Devil's traps" (1). These five prohibitions were for many years 
universally upheld by Bible-believing Christians. Christian institutions 
enforced them, and pastors denounced the forbidden practices as sin. Modern 
neofundamentalists may not openly reject the traditional standards of 
separation, but they increasingly feel that insisting upon them is 
legalistic.
They have adopted popular styles in sacred music.
They tend to be involved in politics, and in politics they do not hesitate 
to make alliances with religious groups that are nonfundamentalist or even 
unorthodox, like the Mormons.
Evangelical churches display many of the same characteristics. So, it 
appears that except for their history, neofundamentalist churches are 
becoming indistinguishable from evangelical churches.
The mark of cultic fundamentalism is its exaltation of one leader to 
spiritual supremacy. At least two fairly large cults have emerged in the 
last twenty years, and more seem to be in the making. The first is the cult 
associated with Jack Hyles and Peter Ruckman. The second is the Bill 
Gothard cult.
The evolving distinctives of the first have clearly heretical tendencies.
Hyles and Ruckman teach that the King James translation of the Bible was 
given by inspiration.
Both men curry the adoration and total submission of their followers.
Both men are tolerant of divorce.
Both men promote ideas that verge on the bizarre (see the articles cited 
below).
The Gothard cult appeals to a different class of people, but is no less 
cultic in its suppression of individual soul liberty. The leader has drawn 
his followers into a way of life that restricts their contact with people 
outside his control and binds them to his leadership for every decision 
they make. What they believe, how they eat, how they manage their practical 
affairs, how they relate to each other, and what they teach their 
children—all require attention to his teachings, some of which are clearly 
unbiblical. For example, he opposes (or at least many of his followers 
believe that he opposes) adoption, giving as his reason that a child of 
immoral parents will inherit their moral weakness.
Excellent critiques of these cults from an orthodox perspective are 
available on the Web. By following the links, you will see informative 
articles on Bill Gothard, Peter Ruckman, and Jack Hyles. I do not agree 
with every position taken, but the articles do well in exposing how far 
these men have strayed from a sound Christianity. (Please inform me if any 
link goes dead.)
comments.author: BobMcDanielRobertson

comments.text:
Apostasy in the Church

Evangelicalism and neoevangelicalism

At the turn of the century, the advances of liberalism alarmed true 
Christians and stirred them to action. They began to cooperate with each 
other in efforts to keep existing church organizations from going liberal. 
Around the time of World War I, a series of books called The Fundamentals 
appeared, defending at length the essential doctrines of Christianity. 
These books were so influential that the new movement which had arisen to 
protest liberalism took its name from them, calling itself fundamentalism.
In the 1920s and 30s, fundamentalists failed to oust liberals from control 
of the mainline denominations. In consequence, fundamentalism itself 
divided into two camps. One warmly embraced the principle of ecclesiastical 
separation—the principle that a local assembly of believers must separate 
itself from apostate Christian organizations. The other took a less 
enthusiastic stance in favor of this principle.
The first camp left mainline denominations and began forming their own 
institutions, including schools, mission boards, and parachurch 
associations. From them came the GARB, the Bible Baptists, the Bible 
Presbyterians, the IFCA, and other groups, as well as many strictly 
independent churches.
The second camp included many who continued the battle of trying to purify 
the mainline denominations, many (especially among the Southern Baptists) 
who did not feel that liberalism threatened their own denomination, and 
many who formed new churches but who maintained dialogue and cooperation 
with more liberal elements in the church.
In time, largely as a result of patronizing the same religious media, the 
second camp coalesced into a distinct movement known as evangelicalism. 
This movement has retained its cohesion even as it has forsaken its 
original identity and evolved into something more modern, tainted with 
apostasy.
Its chief error today is an emphasis on positives to the neglect of 
negatives. Although an evangelical church may faithfully teach the basic 
doctrines of Christianity—the Trinity, the authority of the Bible, 
salvation by faith, and so on—it gives everything a wrong slant. It says 
much about the love of God, but very little about the judgment of God or 
God's hatred of sin. It speaks often of heaven, but seldom of hell. Its 
members hear much about getting to heaven through a commitment to Christ or 
through being born again, but very little about repentance. They listen 
often to promises that the Christian life will make them happy, but seldom 
to warnings about the difficulties and demands of the Christian life. 
Rather than burden them with negative rules and standards, their pastor 
tells them that they have liberty to live as they please, so long as they 
do not break an explicit command of Scripture. As a result, they never 
escape a worldly lifestyle, because many modern vices were unknown in Bible 
times and the Bible says nothing against them.
In the 1950s a small group of Christian intellectuals spearheaded a new 
movement that became known as neoevangelicalism. At the outset, the chief 
distinctive of this movement was its desire to engage learned unbelievers 
in dialogue, seeking not only witness, but also an adjustment of Christian 
language, traditions, and tenets to bring them into agreement with the 
established results of scientific and academic inquiry. Neoevangelicalism 
quickly gained the upper hand at institutions like Fuller Theological 
Seminary and Wheaton College. By now, its influence has been felt 
everywhere in evangelicalism, yet some clear differences between the older 
movement and its spin-off remain.
Most evangelicals are politically conservative, whereas many 
neoevangelicals follow trendy liberal causes. They tend to be pacifistic, 
to favor strong governmental action against social problems, and to support 
advances in minority rights, including the rights of women and homosexuals.
Evangelicals hold to the inerrancy of Scripture, whereas neoevangelicals 
reject inerrancy or else deny that the Creation accounts and other portions 
are meant to be taken literally.
Evangelicals still oppose practices like drinking and smoking, and perhaps 
even rock dancing. Neoevangelicals have no such scruples, although they 
look on smoking as unhealthy and inadvisable, and they endorse moderation 
in drinking.
Evangelicals avoid fellowship with people in the liberal or neo-orthodox 
realm, whereas neoevangelicals willingly interact and fellowship with 
anyone except a fundamentalist.
comments.author: BobMcDanielRobertson

comments.text:
Apostasy in the Church

Neo-orthodoxy

Since World War II, neo-orthodoxy has supplanted liberalism as the dominant 
outlook of mainline churches, although out-and-out liberalism retains many 
adherents, both Protestant and Catholic. The fathers of neo-orthodoxy 
include Karl Barth (called by Billy Graham one of the two greatest 
theologians of our time, the other being Pope John the 23rd), Rudolph 
Bultmann, Emil Brunner, and Reinhold Niebuhr. The essence of neo-orthodoxy 
is its claim that the Bible contains existential rather than factual truth. 
That is, the Bible affords the religious man a valuable, time-honored 
framework for conceptualizing and describing his own personal encounters 
with God (however he conceives of Him).
Neo-orthodoxy permits a worshiper to mouth hymns and creeds that he does 
not really believe. Thus today, if you visit a typical Methodist or 
Lutheran church, you hear liturgies that seem to exalt Father, Son, and 
Holy Spirit, yet when you meet the ministers privately, they will (if they 
are honest) confess their unbelief that the historical Jesus was anything 
more than a man. How do they justify their public affirmations of orthodox 
faith? They regard the language of orthodoxy as simply a vehicle for 
attaining a satisfying religious experience. Subjective experience rather 
than objective truth is, in their view, the foundation of religion.
comments.author: BobMcDanielRobertson

comments.text:
Apostasy in the Church

At the dawn of the twenty-first century, the church of Jesus Christ is sick 
with apostasy, debilitating every missionary work, every Christian school, 
every witness through the media, and every local assembly of believers. The 
apostasy that now fills the whole church germinated in about 1800. Since 
then, it has steadily grown and spread, with corrupting effects that can be 
clearly seen in two ways.
Christianity has fragmented into ideological camps, all of which to some 
degree reject Biblical faith and practice.
Western society as a whole, once composed of nations that prided themselves 
on their allegiance to the Christian religion, has become thoroughly 
secularized.
The sorry state of the contemporary church exactly reproduces all the 
prophetic pictures of the church in the Last Days, on the eve of Christ's 
return. According to prophecy, it would be a church riddled with corruption 
and crippled by apostasy.

Liberalism

Before the eighteenth century, no one who considered himself a Christian 
doubted that the Bible is true, and in European society there were few who 
were willing to say that they were not Christians. But in the eighteenth 
century, the educated elite began to drift away from Christianity toward 
alternative world views conceived by speculative philosophy. The most 
popular of these was deism. Its core belief was that God created the 
universe as a self-perpetuating machine, operating according to natural 
laws discoverable by science. This new world view denied the supernatural, 
as well as God's continuing involvement in human affairs.
In the early nineteenth century, doubt in the supernatural and in Biblical 
history began to infect organized Christianity. The Unitarians, prominent 
in New England, went so far as to reject the full deity of Christ. Under 
the influence of the movement in literature and art known as romanticism, 
many of them believed that God is a mystic oversoul transcending nature yet 
intimately in union with it. That conception of God was called 
transcendentalism.
After the publication of Darwin's Origin of the Species in the 1860s, 
important segments of the church accepted his ideas and abandoned belief in 
the literal truth of the Scriptures. Then emerged a new form of theology 
known as liberalism. Its basic tenets were these:
Although the Bible offers spiritual and ethical insights, it is only a 
collection of human writings. Many of them must be classified as folk tales 
or legends with no historical value.
Jesus may have been divine in the sense that we are all divine, but He was 
not uniquely God. Nor did He exist before His birth. Nor was He born of a 
virgin. Nor did He rise bodily from the grave.
The purpose of life is not personal salvation from sin, but salvation of 
society from the evils of poverty, ignorance, and injustice.
In some of its manifestations, liberalism came close to denying God 
completely, except as a human thought.
By the early 1900s, liberalism had gained control of all the Protestant 
seminaries and had won over many pastors, missionaries, denominational 
overseers, and college officials. Although the average churchgoer was still 
fairly conservative, his leaders were working feverishly to bring his views 
up to date.
But liberalism had an unexpected effect. The average churchgoer had enough 
sense to recognize that if liberalism is right, why go to church? By 
midcentury it became obvious that the mainline churches where liberalism 
was dominant were losing people. So, liberals in religious professions 
began looking for a more appealing theology that would still accommodate 
their unbelief. The new theology that they created is known as 
neo-orthodoxy.
comments.author: BobMcDanielRobertson

comments.text:
Internet research sure did it for me, after 30 years as a Mormon.  It gives 
you the opportunity to research both sides of the issues.  You learn about 
things that you never knew before and then you have the opportunity to 
research it for yourself.  In our defense, we just didn't know about the 
problems, but now we do.  Polygamy had nothing to do with me leaving, 
although at church we were taught that they practiced it in order to 
support the widows of Mormon martyrs, or that the marriages were not 
physical ones.  What can I say?  We believed it.  But no, it wasn't about 
that.  It was about other problems that we just never learned in church and 
I discovered that the list of problems is as long as my arm.  Make that 
both arms.  You try to explain away one or two issues, but at some point 
the evidence is simply indisputable and overwhelming and you realize that 
you've been had and that it's time to walk away.﻿
